s.text: Recent evidence suggested that adrenaline-induced hypokalemia resulted from stimulation of a ?-adrenoceptor linked to membrane Na +/K +-ATPase, causing potassium influx [ 5 28 ] . On the other hand, there was no correlation between serum cate-cholamine level and QTc interval in the present series.
Several in vitro and in vivo experimental studies [ 12 13 14 ] have shown that female sex is a strong risk factor for drug-induced long QT interval and cardiac arrhythmias.
Patients with severe QTc prolongation also had lower serum calcium levels (8.
In order to identify potential risk factors for severe QTc prolongation, univariate analysis was conducted using the ? 2test, Student's t test, or Mann-Whitney U test.
43; P < 0.001) for severe QTc prolongation, while female sex was associated with a relative risk of 3.69 (95% confidence interval 1.27-10.
Multiple logistic regression analysis was then performed to identify independent risk factors for severe QTc prolongation.
The present findings suggest that female sex and hypokalemia are independent risk factors for severe QTc prolongation in patients with SAH.
The multivariate analyses showed that female sex and hypokalemia were independent risk factors for severe QTc prolongation in patients with SAH.
